prior_works.title: Linear theory for control of nonlinear stochastic systems
prior_works.role: Foundational theory: SOC as path-space inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that stochastic optimal control with quadratic control costs can be cast as a KL-regularized path-space inference problem, directly underpinning the paper’s view of control as approximating a target path measure.

prior_works.title: Efficient computation of optimal actions
prior_works.role: Foundational theory: linearly-solvable control / KL control
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced linearly-solvable MDPs where optimal control emerges from KL-regularized objectives, providing the mathematical basis for operating with KL divergences between path measures as used in the trust-region formulation.

prior_works.title: Conservative Policy Iteration
prior_works.role: Algorithmic inspiration: trust-region updates with improvement guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneered monotonic-improvement policy updates via conservative (KL-bounded) steps, inspiring the paper’s use of trust-region constraints to make stable, incremental transport of the path measure toward the target.

prior_works.title: Trust Region Policy Optimization
prior_works.authors: John Schulman, Sergey Levine, Philipp Moritz, Michael I. Jordan, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.role: Algorithmic template: KL trust regions for stable optimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that constraining KL divergence between successive policies yields robust optimization; the paper extends this trust-region principle from policy space to path-space measure transport with explicit KL control.

prior_works.title: Annealed Importance Sampling
prior_works.role: Methodological analogy: geometric annealing between distributions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the geometric annealing paradigm of bridging a prior to a target via intermediate distributions; the paper reinterprets its trust-region updates as a principled annealing schedule with step sizes chosen by KL constraints.

prior_works.title: Diffusion Schrödinger Bridge
prior_works.authors: Valentin De Bortoli, James Thornton, Jeremy Heng, Arnaud Doucet
prior_works.role: Path-space transport and entropic OT link to control and generative modeling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formulated generative modeling as path-space measure interpolation under KL regularization (entropic OT/SB), directly motivating the paper’s path-space transport viewpoint and its applications to diffusion-based sampling.

prior_works.title: Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations
prior_works.authors: Yang Song, Jascha Sohl-Dickstein, Diederik P. Kingma, Abhishek Kumar, Stefano Ermon, Ben Poole
prior_works.role: Application setting: diffusion models as SDEs on path space
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Cast diffusion generative modeling as SDEs over path space, enabling the paper’s application of trust-region path-measure transport to improve diffusion-based sampling and fine-tuning.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core idea—solving stochastic optimal control by iteratively transporting a path-space measure under explicit trust-region (KL) constraints—stands on the fusion of SOC-as-inference and trust-region optimization. Kappen (2005) and Todorov (2009) provide the theoretical backbone: with quadratic control costs, SOC objectives become KL-regularized path-space problems, legitimizing the use of divergences between controlled and prior dynamics as the central optimization primitive. Building on this, Kakade and Langford’s Conservative Policy Iteration and Schulman et al.’s TRPO contribute the crucial operational insight that constraining KL change between successive solutions yields monotonic, stable progress; the present work transposes this trust-region logic from policy distributions to full path measures. Neal’s Annealed Importance Sampling supplies the geometric annealing perspective—constructing a sequence from prior to target—while the proposed trust region determines adaptive, principled step sizes along this annealing path rather than relying on ad hoc schedules. On the generative modeling side, De Bortoli et al.’s Diffusion Schrödinger Bridge connects path-space KL control with entropic optimal transport, aligning directly with the paper’s measure transport view and motivating its application to diffusion processes. Finally, the SDE formulation of diffusion models by Song et al. sets the application context in which path-space updates can be used to enhance sampling and fine-tuning. Together, these works directly inform the paper’s trust-region constrained, annealing-based measure transport algorithm in path space.
